Award.AwardTitle: Science Educators for Urban Schools Phase II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning how to most effectively prepare the next generation of science teachers is essential for improving science learning for all students. The Science Educators for Urban Schools Phase 2 (SEUS 2) project at Boston College aims to support a total of 20 Scholars who are enrolled in the Masters of Education in Science Education program to prepare for initial licensure in secondary science and preliminary licensure in middle school general science through the Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase II program. SEUS 2 is a comprehensive urban teacher preparation program in the sciences that: i) includes effective strategies to recruit highly qualified and diverse applicants, a rigorous STEM teacher preparation curriculum, established support programs for pre- and in-service teachers, and opportunities for professional development; and ii) prepares the scholars to become and remain science teachers in urban schools. By developing and supporting additional highly qualified and diverse STEM teachers with Sheltered English Immersion endorsement who will teach in urban schools, the SEUS 2 program will address the Nation's shortage of science teachers, as described in the National Academies' report Rising Above the Gathering Storm (2007) and the recent Teacher Shortage Area Nationwide List (2013). Moreover, an emphasis on recruiting scholars from underrepresented minority groups to serve as role models as teachers and the emphasis on social justice, which can be critical in maintaining motivation working in high-need schools, provide additional ways this project has broad significance to society.

The SEUS 2 project will contribute to the existing body of knowledge by implementing and studying a model for developing and supporting an urban STEM teacher preparation program and adding to understanding about science teacher education and retention. The project will build upon a recent successful Noyce Scholarship Phase I award, in which all 20 scholars who were supported are currently remain teaching science in urban schools. The project will also leverage the existing Donovan Urban Scholars Program, high-quality support structures for new teachers, and strong relationships with six urban school districts including Boston Public Schools through the Boston Higher Education Partnership and community partners through Boston Connects. SEUS 2 will feature a rigorous teacher preparation program that adds a required Behavior Management course into the curriculum, additional internal recruitment activities beyond existing internal and external recruitment strategies, scholar participation in classroom-based research to improve science achievement in an urban context, a classroom-based performance assessment via a Master's Comprehensive Examination, biweekly online discussions for previous and current SEUS scholars, and support for new teachers to participate in NSTA conferences. The mixed methods evaluation plan and research investigations that include qualitative case studies, as well as monitoring, semi-structured interviews and year-end surveys of all SEUS scholars will increase the likelihood that the SEUS model for developing and supporting an urban STEM teacher education program can be adapted at other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 6 years (2014-2020) the Robert Noyce Foundation has generously funded Science Educators for Urban Schools 2 (S.E.U.S. 2). This grant has supported 18 students who graduated with a degree in science to acquire licensure and endorsement to teach science (7-12) in content areas of biology, chemistry, earth/environmental/geological science, and physics. All graduates except the most recent Scholar (2020) are teaching in urban public schools. This is a major outcome given that current attrition rates of urban, public, school teachers range from 58% to 78% for 3-year and 43% to 64% for 5-year teachers (Papay, Bacher-Hicks, & Page, 2017). Due to COVID-19, hiring in many urban schools is “frozen” as resources are supporting remote, hybrid, and/or eventual face-to-face learning and making schools safe for re-entry; thus, the Scholar is currently teaching high school and adults in a Boston literacy center but has applications on file at several urban schools in major urban districts.  All Scholars completed a BS or BA in biology, chemistry, earth/environmental science or physics, with the average undergraduate GPA of all Scholars being 3.62 and the average graduate GPA, 3.82.

 

Of the SEUS 2 cohort of 18, 6 are persons of color, 11 are females, 7 are males, 10 are bilingual, and 1 is trilingual with Spanish being the most common second language, and Korean the second most common language. Of the cohort, 10 have licenses in biology, 3 in chemistry, 3 in physics, and 2 in earth/environmental science, with 9 having additional licenses in middle school teaching as well as high school chemistry, environmental science, biology, and mathematics. All Scholars are highly qualified, having passed all Massachusetts Tests of Educator Licensure and received endorsement from the CAEP-accredited Lynch School of Education and Human Development Teacher Preparation Program, Sheltered English Instruction Endorsement from the state of Massachusetts, and Teaching English Language Learner Certificates as well as additional support in behavioral classroom management. All report having the necessary content, pedagogy, and pedagogical content knowledge to teach urban students and to teach in urban schools. Scholars are currently teaching in urban public schools in Boston, San Jose, Seattle, Chicag, New York City, New Haven, as well as other smaller urban, public school districts. The average student load per teacher is 85 students, which suggests that on average, these teachers impact the lives of ~1450 students yearly. Almost all teachers have participated in funded conferences such as AERA, NSTA, and state association conferences and have attained or are working toward attaining professional licensure in their subject matter areas, as they continue to improve subject matter and pedagogical knowledge while sharing their own classroom research.

 

Critical outcomes of SEUS 1 and 2 have been recounted in publications: new teacher agency, pedagogical context knowledge, and negotiating sociopolitical variables that often lead to new teacher attrition especially in urban schools. Our research on S.E.U.S. 1 (2008-2013) and S.E.U.S. 2 (2014-2020) Scholars demonstrates that despite the variables unique to urban public schools, such as the lack of human and material resources, intensive focus on literacy and math instruction due to high-stakes assessments, traditional instruction in lieu of more innovative practices articulated in NGSS, unsupportive administration, and colleagues that are tired or disinterested, our graduates have negotiated difficult contexts, enhanced pedagogy, navigated obstructive socio-political contexts, developing more refined pedagogical context knowledge, and remained teaching. Of the 41 teachers the Robert Noyce Foundation has supported via grant funding (S.E.U.S. 1 and 2), 34 are still teaching in urban public schools, clearly beating the odds, while 1 earned a Ph.D. in Science Education, 3 are enrolled in Science Education doctoral programs, 1 is a physician’s assistant, and 1 is working in technology. For all, relationships with students and love of science and teaching have critically impacted their decisions to remain teaching in urban schools and in science-related fields. Although several are still making sense of the best ways to integrate students’ needs and the economic, cultural, and political aspects of the neighborhoods and larger communities in which they teach in order to provide more authentic, culturally relevant and responsive instruction, these Scholars are commited to improving science learning and the life chances of all they serve!
